text: well it's very simple he got it wrong I
see the Telegraph headline robbed at the
death and they speak to David Denton
afterwards who said that the bounce of
the ball has changed our lives for the
next four years it's unbelievable he
said he went to met with his family
afterwards and you could have filled a
bathtub with the tears all the players
and the dressing room were crying it's
the code of model ethics in rugby that
the referees decision is final
you did not see I'd love to have seen
Jose Mourinho reaction after that had it
been an equivalent incident in football
the Scottish players accepted the
referees decisions final they asked him
to go to the television match official
but you can only go to the television
match official officially if it's a
incident of foul play or it leads to a
try and has the build-up to the try
being okay but I spoke to three famous
international referees last night all of
them said that in that particular
incident they would go to the television
match official but can I say this the
television match official the to touch
judges and the referee Zubair just
before that line out Stuart Hoggett
cleared the ball from his own 22 up deep
into this a half of Australia and after
he kicked it he was then later smashed
out of the field of play flew through
the air and hog said I ended up in the
front row of the grandstand it was a
late tackle it should have been picked
up by Ben skiing the TMO he should have
alerted the referee the referee should
have seen it also both touch judges
should have and it should have been a
penalty to Scotland's absolutely no
question about that but the television
match official whose job is to watch it
and it was there on the television
screen smashed into touch that was a
penalty to Scotland however they missed
it it then came to the line out
immediately after it was won by Denton
it went back
Scotland's flanker John Hardy knocked it
on it was then picked up by John Welsh
in front of him he would have been
offside however it was touched by Hardy
Nick Fitz the scrum-half
then
touched it the Australian scrum-half and
that immediately meant that when he
flicked it back it touched his chest
both hands and he flicked it back and he
admitted afterwards that he knew what he
was doing he admitted it and that meant
John Welsh was onside and the penalty
shouldn't have been awarded well you
know you then saw what the Gavin
Hastings described as despicable and
disgusting and Matt Dawson in the
commentary box agreed
the referee sprinted off the pitch 50
metres and to cut the Telegraph at the
speed of Usain Bolt so that suggested he
had guilt on his conscience well that's
a very comprehensive answer to one
question and full of detail
